theunidealwoman: Hey! Although I agree with the fact that this happens and no marketing jargon should be able to justify such attacks on the body and your self worth. Now instead of viewing this as a consequence of her "socialisation" you are tending to blame her because it directly impacted you or could impact you. If we do not acknowledge the nuances that are at play when it comes to body positivity or understanding the dynamics of gender, it will be futile to create awareness in the social media on issues . She is NOT ranting about where she comes from, IT is a FACT. And she would not have gotten all the education, exposure, or the platform to have understood the things that you are talking about. There is marked difference in the accessibility, affordability and quality of resources between the two of you. dyotanab: The post seems to be oblivious towards the structural problems that shape different class realities ( in your own word ‘struggle’) for different people. The sales/service woman’s desperation to sell cosmetics is not just about reinforcing market dictated insecurities around body and beauty, but a clear indication of what she, as a service industry working class thinks would be sellable to an upper/middle class woman. Mocking the sales person about her consumer choice and trivialising or generalising their struggle with women across class indicates a misplaced understanding of emancipatory politics.
